text: This video tutorial will show you
how to set a Siri shortcut
for when you're being pulled over.

The shortcut will make Siri
perform a list of commands
once you activate the shortcut.

The shortcut activates the
do not disturb feature,
sends a text message to chosen contacts,

sends your current location
to chosen contacts,
starts recording video,

and sends that video to
your chosen contacts.
Before setting the Siri shortcut,

you may have to enable untrusted
shortcuts on your phone.
Open the link in the description below
in your iPhone's internet browser.

It will open the I'm Getting
Pulled Over shortcut app,
created by Robert Peterson.

Select which contacts
will receive a message
with your location and then tap continue.
You'll also have to select

who will receive a copy
of the recorded video.
On the My Shortcuts tab,
tap "All Shortcuts,"
then tap the three dots
on the Getting Pulled Over shortcut.
In the camera section,
choose whether you want the back
or front camera to start recording
when the shortcut is activated

and choose where you
want to store your video.

Tapping the red minus option
will delete a location,
and tapping the green plus will add one.

Once set up, you'll have
to activate the shortcut
whenever you'd like to use it.
Activate Siri by holding the lock button
or home button down,
depending on your iPhone model.

You can also say, "Hey,
Siri," if it's enabled.

Once the screen indicates
Siri's listening,
say, "I'm getting pulled over."
This will activate the shortcut.
You can also activate the shortcut
by opening up the Shortcuts app.
